title: BHP wants one of its own for next CEO, chairman says
text:
London | BHP is actively grooming internal candidates to replace long-serving CEO Andrew Mackenzie, the mining giant's chairman Ken MacKenzie has revealed.

Mr MacKenzie told reporters after the company's London annual general meeting on Thursday (early Friday AEDT) that BHP was working with potential internal successors to bring them up to the required standard.

'An ongoing process' ... BHP chairman Ken MacKenzie. Jessica Shapiro

The company has been under pressure to reveal more about its succession planning after a UBS survey of BHP investors found the seven-year tenure of Mr Mackenzie and selection of his replacement was the second biggest concern facing BHP investors, after the trajectory of the iron ore price.

"What we do as a board, and what we've been doing since I became chairman, so that's over the last two years, is we have identified a profile of what we think the next CEO should look like," Mr MacKenzie said.

"And we're benchmarking all the internal candidates against that profile, identifying gaps, putting in place development programs, and then working with our internals around closing the gaps."
description: The mining giant is grooming internal candidates to replace the long-serving Andrew Mackenzie.
